pageContext.desc: The activist and physician's papers relating to his work for Indian rights.
pageContext.category: Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Collection; Letters (Correspondence); Indians of North America; Records (Documents)

pages.transcription:
May 21
Dear Doctor
I am at Okoboji and having a fine time. I am all alone, and maybe you think I don't have fun getting something to eat.
Haven't had time to go fishing yet, as the folks told me to do some painting etc. "Work before play always." Wish you were here to see some of the big fish some of the other fellows catch, but they told me they would

leave a few of the large ones for the "Doctor" when he came, so don't worry for there will be some left.
About our trip. Dont you think I could buy everything I will need in Kansas City? Then I could have your advice. Of course I will take my old clothes, but I mean the other things which we will have to buy.
My "chum" says he will get my ticket all right, so that much is fixed.

We had a letter from George just before I left home and she is having a fine time. I will be alone up here until June first. Got through my examinations in law with a grade of above 90 in everything, and it make father feel fine. Write and tell me all you know
Yours Very Truly
Erin
Okoboji In.

in Des Moines. We had a game of base ball today and I had the honor of playing first base for D.U. We won over the Des Moines Dental School by a score of 7 to 3. There is nothing much doing in D.M. so I'll talk or write a little about our plans for next summer.

Ap 4, 1905
Dear Doctor,
This evening I took a long ride on my wheel and got up a good sweat. I then took a bath and now I will take time enough to write a short letter to you. 
I saw in the paper the other day that Chicago was covered with two feet of snow, is that right? There is now sign of winter left

This is the way I have figured it. My school lets out May 15th and I go to Okoboji at once. The folks come up the first of June. Then you come up the second week in June so George will have to get there before you come. Then we will stay at Okoboji as long as we think best, and from there strike for the West to stay as long as you think best. My school begins about the 5th or 6th of September.

   I think the greatest evil of today in America is, that people work too hard and too long without vacation. "All work and no play makes

I think he is about the finest old man I ever saw.
In your next letter I wish you would state your ideas as to what would be the best plan for next summer as you know a great deal more about it than I do. I think that trip West will be the finest thing on earth, and it will put me in fine shape for

Jack a dull boy." Of course I am only a kid and may not know much about what I am talking about, but that is the way I look at it. What do you think about it?
I had a fine letter from Dr Gravens yesterday. You remember him dont you? He has baught the largest gas launch on Lake Okoboji.

foot ball next fall, with you as a trainer.
Yours very truly
Em 4/4/05

Sat. 10:30 A.M.
My dear Dr. Montezuma:
I am in town for a few hours only - leave at 3 - could you take a little time off and go to lunch with us? If so - please meet us at the office of Dr. Nellie Flint - 7th floor of Marshall Field Annex as soon after one as possible - I have a friend with me - who is a friend of yours - but you must wait and see who it is.
I trust you can arrange your affairs so that you may lunch us? If so please meet us at the office of Dr. Nellie Flint of the floor of Marshall Field Annex as soon after one as possible. 
I have a friend with me who is a friend of yours but you must wait and see who it is.
I trust you can arrange your affairs so that you may lunch

with us.
I will spend the hour from 12 to 1 - with Dr. Flint.
Sincerely,
Georgetta Witter

n.d.
Friday evening.
My dear Dr. Montezuma - This has been a cold busy week - the coldest of the winter and I might say the busiest. My outside work has been especially heavy this week besides an examination yesterday.
I am getting tired - wonder if I can get along until Spring? Really - with the spirit we have to fight at Drexel it takes an extra amount of strength - unless you can be content to let your work slide - and that I cannot do.
We are having vacation Monday in honor of Washingtons birthday - most everyone has gone home to spend Sunday. Miss. Wilking (my room mate) went down to Wilmington this morning - she will return

Tuesday. Mr. White is spending his time at Washington & Baltimore. Miss. Adams comes over tomorrow to stay with me until Monday. Mrs. Dillard was just in to pay her party call. She is such a nice lady - I admire her very much. She sends her kindest regards. The other day (Wednesday) I made a fruit cake - it must stand a while before cutting . but when I cut it I will send some your way. Miss. Dunlap has just been in and 'talked an [aren?] off." - wonder why women like to talk? I still have the green part of the flowers you brought me - even they brighten up the room.
Very Sincerely,
Georgetta Witter.

Sept. 22nd
My dear Dr. Motezuma - According to present plans I expect to reach Chicago next Saturday morning and will surely call & see you. Thank you for the kind invitation to stop at your home - I will be a very short time in your city and must see a good many people so I can not take advantage of your kind offer. Nevertheless I appreciate it.
If for any reason, I change my plans I will surely let you know.
Sincerely,
Georgette Witter.

My dear Dr. Montezuma - It is almost dinner time - where the day has gone I can't tell - really - a week slips by and it seems only a day. Guess that is a sure sign I'm getting old. This morning we played basket ball. You know the great cup game comes off Thursday at four and we do want to win. March 21st we have a "show off" day - "show off" classes in every line of work and I have been selected to give a "show off demonstration in Invalid Cookery - Of course this means

a good bit of extra work and where the time is coming from I can't tell - because I am as busy as I can be now.
Last Saturday & Sunday I spent with Miss. Adams - she is such a true - big - hearted girl - I will be so sorry to leave her next June.
Saturday afternoon we saw Mrs. Leslie Carter in Du Barry and if she comes to Chicago be sure & see her. But before you go read up your French History - the period of Louis XV and you will get much more out of the play.
Sunday morning Miss Adams

and I went down to Christ Church - where Washington worshiped during his six years in Philadelphia - and as Sunday was his birthday we heard special services. Every thing is just as it was several hundred years ago and we had a very pleasant morning.
Tonight it is raining and blowing and we dread the walk to dinner - but are going nevertheless. Mrs. Dillard and Miss Adams ask to be remembered to  you.
Sincerely,
Georgetta Witter

Sunday
My dear Dr. Montezuma - your good letter came yesterday - I am well again and have been intending to write - but after a weeks absence, I find I have quite a bit of extra work to do - and then - I have been running about some.
Yesterday was the opening day at the Delaware Country Club. Prof. White is a member and he said he felt sure a day in the country would do me good. I thought so too - so we spent the day out in West Chester - about nine miles west of Philadelphia.

-2-
The club house has been an old farm house - it is now remodelled & fitted up as an up-to-date club house. The grounds are beautiful - golf links, tennis courts - cricket & baseball grounds. There the woods - they are so restful - and I picked such a bunch of spring flowers - I walked miles & miles and came home tired & happy - ready for a good nights sleep. Today we went over in North Philadelphia to the Temple to hear Dr. Russell Conwell preach. I enjoyed every minute. We had dinner with a friend of Miss Wilkings & since then have called on two of the girls.

-3-
You see it has been a busy Sunday for me and I still have my home letter to write. Mamma writes that [Glenn?] is well again - she has a good girl - but papa has the grip. I hope he is getting along well - I always worry when he gets sick.
I am waiting to hear about the dinner -
Very Sincerely,
Georgetta Witter

Sunday afternoon
My dear Dr. Montezuma - I am so glad the "turn out" was a success. I am sure Bert enjoyed it - it was just the sort of a thing he likes. He is one of the jolliest boys I ever knew and our friendship has been little short of ideal.
I wish I might have been where I could peep in - not come in - because then you wouldn't have been the same - but where I could look in unobserved. Yesterday we (the basketball girls) had our pictures taken - will show them to you next summer. Next Sunday I go down to Trenton, N. J. to

-2- 
spend Sunday with Miss Wilking I expect to visit Atlantic City & Wilmington during our few days vacation. 
Only a few moor weeks - six - then I go home to give some demonstrations in Invalid Cookery in Mercy Hospital - will be at home until about June 15th then up at Okoboji - where I hope to get a good rest. Mamma writes she has excellent help now - for which I am very thankful.
Do you know when Bert expects to leave Chicago?
Pardon the short letters - but as time grows shorter I have the more to do.
Sincerely
Georgetta Witter

Wednesday A.M.
My dear Dr. Montezuma: We are expecting you Friday - I wrote - telling you how to find 3331 Walnut St. but for fear the letter did not reach you I will say again. Go to Walnut St. & take an Angora or Darby car going west. Get off at 34th & you are only a few houses away. I am so busy - so busy - but I'm going to have a half holiday Friday. Hope you are having a successful commencement.
Sincerely
Georgetta Witter

Jan. 28 - 1902
My dear Dr. Montezuma - the thumb is better again - and my how I have to work to make up for lost time.
The coming two weeks are the final weeks of the first semester and with them come all of our final examinations. Then our series of "Cup Games" is on for the Basket Ball team and that means work.
Next semester I am to get quite a deal of outside teaching - one class especially, I am looking forward to with a great deal of pleasure - it is a "deaconess" class - of ten ladies. As to the trip to Carlisle - I am trying my best to arrange my work to come - Thursday & Friday are my teaching days and if we have work those days I must stay -

there is no other way, but I will see if I can arrange to have the work come on other days. If I come I would surely like to bring Miss. Adams with me. But it can't be decided yet. We must wait until Miss Springs decides it.
I have been so situated this last week that the home folks have not had a letter - tonight I have written a long one and my thumb is getting tired.
I will write when I hear from Miss. Spring.
Sincerely
Georgetta Witter

lazy. We came home by Salt Lake and Denver - reached Des Moines Feb. 1st.
Miss. Van [Liew?] sends her kindest regards.
I trust that I may hear all about your trip and enjoy a visit with you, sometime in the near future.
Sincerely,
Georgetta Witter
1325 Center St.

April, 19 - 1902 -
My Dear Dr. Montezuma: I was delighted to know that you remembered me. It was a disappointed not to find you in Chicago - not knowing your office hours I supposed they would be from eleven to [unclear] for so they are in Des Moines; but I'll be down there some time in the near future and then I hope to see you. You know my brother is in school at Northwestern so we go down every few weeks.

I am sure you had a fine trip and I would enjoy hearing you tell about it: I have always wanted to take such a trip as that and next best to going one'sself is to have some one describe it to you.
I know of nothing I would enjoy more than a "turn out". and if "being natural" is one of the characteristics of an Indian then I'm 2/3 Indian.
We had a very pleasant winter - were in or about Los Angeles most of the time. I did some work in the University - just enough to keep from getting

Sept 15 - 1902
My dear Dr. Montezuma - I had expected to be in Chicago [unclear] this but my plans have been changed and I will be there next week - probably about Thursday - and hope to see you at that time.
I suppose you are always busy - but if you will tell me when you are the least busy I will try and see you then.
My dearest friend starts for Europe next week and I go as far as New York with her - when

I call I will bring her with me for I want you to know her. She's small - but true as gold.
I have many things to say but will leave them until next week.
Em sends his kindest regards - says he will write and tell you the truth about the fish he (caught?).
Until I see you -
Sincerely
Georgetta Witter

Philadelphia - Penn.
Sept - 30 - 1902
My dear doctor: I am not going to thank you for the beautiful flowers or the delicious candy - I am only going to tell you how we appreciated them - the flowers we kept until today - our first meal in our own room was last night and the flowers that adorned the table came with us from Chicago.

2
the helped us on the way - we wore the Sunday - and did so enjoy them.
Our little visit in your city was one of the brightest places of the journey - it will always have a place in our memory. We have a very pleasant room - just opposite the campus of the University of Pennsylvania - and in this house are several collage fellows.
You will pardon this

pencil - but we haven't purchased any ink yet - and I wanted to write tonight.
Very Sincerely
Georgetta Witter
3331 Walnut St.
Please don't forget to tell us the names of your friends here - Miss. Miller is anxious to have them.

enough they say.
We are so busy and so happy, these are the live things that make life worth living.
Sincerely
Georgetta Witter
3331 Walnut St.

Philadelphia - Penn
Oct. 9 - 1902
My dear Dr. Montezuma - we are enjoying Philadelphia - so much. We are greatly pleased with the work we are doing at Drexel - is just what we want. Our home life is ideal. We seem to fit each other exactly. That means a great deal - I can tell you. We still do our own house keeping - such jolly times - We often speak of you - and say -

Dr. Montezuma would enjoy this meal. And I know you would.
As you say - it (our friendship) has been mostly greetings and goodbyes - but each time we know each other better - and parting is sweet sorrow when we think of the meeting that comes after the parting. 
We were afraid you wouldn't get off the train that day - and we laughed when we thought what a joke it would be if you couldn't.
Last Saturday I was down in Wanamakers store - they have a display of Indian baskets. I was looking at them - when a man came up and asked me if I know the name of the Indians that made a certain basket. I did and told him - then he began to talk of Indians & their life. I discovered he had spent fifteen years in the West - mostly Los Angeles - had owned one of the largest curio stores there - and was a friend of Prof. James. Wasn't it odd that here in a city like Philadelphia where I am a stranger - that I should meet him?
Miss. Miller is over in the laboratory - I am excused from Chemistry - have had

Philadelphia, Penn
Oct. 19 - 1902
My dear Dr. Montezuma: We have been working hard - too hard I fear - as a result we are getting tired and nervous - so I  have decided to take a day off and spend it with my friends - letters are poor things yet they are a great comfort to us after all. My work is very heavy 26 1/2 hrs a week in the class room - of course all our studying is extra. I spend seven successive hours, on Thursdays, in the laboratory on food analysis. After that I play basket ball for an hour - you see I have an ambition to be on the winning basket ball team. There are only 128 girls trying for the place - so theres seems

to be a small chance of my getting on the team but nevertheless - I'm trying.
Last Wednesday evening our class had it first regular meeting. It was election of officers - and you know the lady they elected president - her name is Georgetta Witter. Of course I am highly honoured - and I will do my very best to make our class what it should be.
Tomorrow evening we have a treat in store - we are going to hear Viola Allen in "The Eternal City" and more than that - Hall Caine has travelled all the way from London, to hear, this - his best play - and he will be here tomorrow evening for the first time. Won't it be great to watch him and see if he likes the [eilir partition?] given?
Indeed we will see the Penn. - Carlisle game - we had spoken of that before your letter came. Penn - was defeated yesterday - 15 to 6 to Brown - we told the people here - wait until the Indians get after you - and they only groaned - the very thoughts of it hurt.
We too look forward to Commencement time - what a jolly time we will have.
Look out for some of our cooking.
Sincerely
Georgetta Witter

we have fun?
Yes - we saw Viola Allen - she was fair - not excellent - she became so dramatic that she lost sight of the woman - and if Roma was one thing above another she was a woman. Edward Morgan as David was ideal - so sincere - earnest - simple - he was truly great.
If you remember - the book has a sad ending - but the drama is changed - David & Roma are united - David placed high in offical life and every body is happy.
I enjoy a good play - have no time to spend on any other kind - unless I am made better by going I would rather stay away.
We are still busy and happy - Domestic Science is such a broad subject - the study of food so interesting - would that every woman could have a course before making a home of her own
Don't forget about the colors.
Sincerely
Georgetta Witter

Oct. 28 -1902
My dear Doctor Montezuma - I am 
afraid Chicago is too much for you - at - 
least Saturday s

foot ball team. Saturday evening the bell rang- there were four fellows bringing the poor fellow home. He had been treated pretty rough in the game- had a blow on the head and a twisted knee. Well we all took hot water bottles- ice [???] - hot tea- linement- rub downs. in just- any thing or every thing up to him. Poor boy- he is better now.
The boy that rooms next to us has been ill for some days- poor fellow- he is only nineteen and away from home for the first time. He is taking denistry- as you know the dentists & medics have the same course the first year. Its a good heavy years work at best and this boy has only had two years in high school. No physics- no chemistry- he is taking - or trying to take second year chemistry - its no wonder he's sick,

Philadelphia, Pa. 
Dec. 6 - 1902
My dear Doctor Montezuma - I wonder if you have met Bert yet? He expected to call on you last week. Now let me tell you who Bert is. A classmate of mine - Drake '98 - and one of the best boy friends I have. He lived in our home for some time and I think most as much of him I do of my brothers. He is a bright fellow - came to Drake a poor boy - worked his way thro' school - when he finished & was given a position as assistant in Latin & for the past two years has been head of the department. This year he is working for his doctors degree. I hope you will meet & like him.

Last week my chum from home visited me - I spent much time with her - then, besides - I was given some teaching to do. So I find my self buried with work - but by tomorrow I will be caught up again.
I can't say yet- about my vacation - I would like to go home - because it is very probable that I will spend the summer in New York. I have a position in sight there. If I don't go home, mamma will spend the week with me here.

Was down town yesterday - it almost made me sad to think what a very little time I have to devote to getting little gifts for my friends. I have already sent

(en)joyed the work so much. However, I love them none the less and the time may come when I will have more leisure to devote to them.
Of I go home. I expect to spend the day in Chicago, so we will have another "flying visit". I look forward to the trip with great pleasure. I enjoy travelling alone. Strange, but it is so.
At present we are having awful weather- snow, rain and hail- not much like last winter for me.
I must [go] to those lessons, let me hear from you soon for your letters do me lots of good.
Very sincerely,
Georgetta Writter

My time is also limited.  I leave at a cost which unknown
I go there to pay my respects.  I leave Carlisle, 6 oclock
I will arrive in Philadelphia there about 10 oclock
I remain until 4 oclock which time I fly back to Chicago.
My stay in Philadelphia will be short as I am due in Chicago Saturday evening  crossed out "to address"

Jan. 28 - 1903
My dear Dr. Montezuma,
I simply can't get off - Wednesday I am busy all day- Thurs. morning our Practical Cooking + Thursday afternoon teaching- Friday morning work and at noon a basket ball game which the girls say I must not miss and it could be mean for me to run away and leave them in the most critical game - after I have worked with unclear all winter. After two o'clock Friday I am free -

You come on to Phila. and meet some of my friends here.  I wish I had a home where I could entertain you - but I haven't it. - but we will manage to have you meet a few people anyway.  I will ask some of my dearest friends to lunch or dinner and we will enjoy that.  Now tell me what day - (or days) you will be here so I can get the people.  I am sorry not to go to Carlisle - but I am here to get all I can out of my school work and seems wiser

I crossed out - "regret very much" am really sorry that you so busily engaged in school that it will be crossed out "interfere" for you to attend Carlisle Commencement impressible withnot unknown
That you for your kind unknown to make [[crossed out "a unknown about"]] you a visit. Ill unknown and to meeting your friends, do you not think

for me to stay.
Very Sincerely
Georgetta Witter

Feb. 5th 1903
My dear Dr. Montezuma,
I am expecting you next Friday, and I have asked a very few of my best friends to dinner that evening. I am very anxious for you to meet them. I have a basketball game from 12 to 1, but I will be seeable by two or shortly after. Will you come to the house? You know the number and if you go to Walnut St. take a Darby or Augora car going west and get off at 34th St. you are only a few houses from where I live. We can have a visit before it is time to go to dinner. I know you will enjoy the commencement - and I am sure it would have been a great pleasure to me if I had been

Mar. 26
'03
My dear Dr. Montezuma - I'm better - in school. Trying to make up what I lost during my absence of five days. Wish I could see & be with you at your dinner. Will write the last of the week.
Sincerely
Georgetta Witter
March 26 - 1903

April 13 - 1903
My dear Dr. Montezuma, 
My last day in Philadelphia, tomorrow I go down to New York and on Wednesday sail on the "Potsdam" for France.
I have packed all my things and sent them home. The room looks very bare and I was a wee mite lonesome when the box of Easler sweeys arrived, it made pleasant the rest of the day. I thank you. Today brought word of the illness of my baby brother, mamma says he has been very ill, but is better now, able to sit up, but she didn't want to worry me while I was busy. She knew I wouldn't go if I had

-2-
known he was ill. I am so thankful he is getting along well. Write me so I will get it when I reach Paris, send it to 32 Boil des Italiens, Paris, France.
Will write on the boat.
Sincerely,
Georgetta Writter

May 15 - 1903
Paris, France
My dear Dr. Montezuma,
Still in Paris, but not tired of Paris. I would that I could spend a year in this city. There are so many things of interest here. Old palaces, and these I enjoy very much, not because they were the home of royalty, but on account of their connection with history.
The french people are the happiest people I ever saw. Give them something to wear and a piece of bread and it is all they ask. The laugh, sing and dance with not a care in the world. 
Here they have double decker trains

-2-
and from the top of one of these you can see the life of Paris as in no other way. The trains go where you wouldn't care to walk and then when you are out of it you an excellent view of things
I haven't time to write much, today is mail day so this will be only a note.
Kindest regards.
Sincerely,
Georgetta Writter

R. F.  Railsback, 
Editor-in-chief
W. A. Fraser,
Manager
'99 Illio.
University of Illinois.
Champaign.
Dr. Carlos Montezuma,
100 State St.,
Chicago.
Dr Montezuma,-
It was very careless of me to delay so long in answering your kind letter of the fourth, but it was several days before I could see Mr. Railback, the editor, and I have been very busy - I fear five hundred words will give you a very small chance to discuss the Indian question, but we will be very glad of such an article.
Very sincerely,
Luke C. Moolsey
1310 So. Springfield Ave.,
Urbana, Illinois,
December eleventh, ninety-seven (1897)

(Two Cents stamp on top right corner)
Dr Montezuma.
Dear Sir,
My friend Miss Luzena Choteau gave me a letter of introduction to you a year ago, and as I have decided to leave Washington, I thought it better to write to you first, I am a practical nurse, willing to take any contagions, disease to nurse, I can furnish the best of references from Doctor's. Will and Kindly tell me if their is any opening their for nurses as I would like to come West.
Thanking you kindly for any information or suggestions you may give.
Very Respect.,
Mrs L. E. Wright.
Mrs. L. E. Wright 1587 -- 15th St. N. W. Washington, D. C. Dec. 8, 1901.

A conveyance is waiting for me to go to the city -- therefore I must close.  Have written very hastily therefore excuse the scrawly letter.
Wish you would show the Carlisle team up in its proper light after the season is over.
I do not believe the school should be permitted to have such a team.  So long as itis no other Indian school can expect to keep anyone of any athletic ability in school to finish his education.  Indian boys are just like other boys and where salaries are offered to them, they sooner or later accept.
Please consider this strictly confidential.
Very truly, indistinguishable

I could go on giving you information of a simliar nature about the make up of the Carlisle team but am in a hurry.  I do not want you to think I am jealous.  I am not.  I like to see Indians win but the management of the Carlisle School ought to be ashamed to call the team a school team.  It is a strictly professional team and all kinds of inducements are held out to Indians to go to Carlisle to play.  Many a young man who would otherwise be in school completing his education is influenced to quit school and play football.  Why should Harvard, indistinguishable + Chic. play this professional team?  Money is the answer.
me to think you are sacrificing pleasures for me -- so you must not -- Do you hear?  Affectionately your sister --Jannette

n.d.
2007? W unclear St.
Champaign IL
woman--image
Dear unclear Monta.?
You are no good unclear and I, especially myself that I feel like a little villian in consequence I am always in the unclear of writing nice long letters and telling you how much I appreciate you as a unclear and how hard I am trying to do as you would like, but somehow the time flys and I never are near a pen & paper when I do have unclear. But you must not think? of me as working? so

I am on my way to school,  unclear is just ready to go but as I was here at the table and had a few minutes I signed the  unclear to dash off a letter now to you. I do hope you are well and have unclear of nice features to and am glad to hear that all are doing well. Mrs.  Sarveyer? of the Ch. Hospital was down here a little while ago and she speaks nicely of you.  Well I must go but will try and write fewer and thank you much a thousand turns for your generosity, but it worries

extremely hard for unclear would not be correct - the fact is I have tried not to work so hard unclear unclear to keep well - I am tired most of the time and so spend much valuable time in doing nothing at all because I can't - but still my studies are going very well indeed - especially the music and art. unclear unclear unclear - to me unclear she met you at the unclear, I believe, and that you spoke so kindly and hopefully of me, and unclear I won't disappoint you, I promise you, if I once am good and strong.

United States Indian Service,
White Earth Agency, Minn
Oct 4th, 1892
Dr. Carlos Montezuma
White Rock
Nevada
Sir,
I am in neeedful of your favour of Sept 6th Making inquiry of the number of unclear that speak English unclear exact number I am unable to tell but think than one half can speak and understand English quite well. we have 6853 Indians all told in this agency I hope this information will answer your Inquiry quite sufficient

I am Respectfully
B. [[unclear]
U.S. Indian Agt.

THE CHICAGO RECORD-HERALD
FRANK B. NOYES, EDITOR AND PUBLISHER
Dec 26 07
Hail Great Chief - Does not the great chief Know that his very hale? face brother has been on the war path in New York for several moons and a dozen or so suns and is but now returned to his tribal home. The very hale? face brother mourns that he was not at the great pow wow in the great chief's camp

THE CHICAGO RECORD-HERALD
FRANK B. NOYES, EDITOR AND PUBLISHER
2
on Dec 18th but for several days before and after he was drinking fire water among the [[unclear[[ and the Broadwayches?. Only today did he receive your birch bark. He is now beating his breast and lamenting that he missed the great powwow and begs that the heart of the great chief be not turned against him but that he wil again summon him to council.
Signed unclear H Little?

Haskell Institute
Lawrence, Kansas
Nov?.18. 1907
Dear Dr. Montezuma.
Replying to your letter up the 15th. just received, I am glad to give you the following information:
W.Gardner was formerly a pupil of this school and played on our second football team. He was a good student and a clean felow.
Wauseka], (unclear Kauser or Hauser?) was a student for 3 years and after that an assistant employe for a short time. He was a young man of unclear ability but liked athletics better than school and finally gave up school work entirely. He took to drinking during the time that he was employed here and finally had to be discharged. 
Afraid of a Bear, (Samuel McClaiux?) was a student for four years at Haskell, He left at the end of the last year because he

2
Department of the Interior,
United States Indian Service,
was offered a salary to go to Carlisle.
Mr. Claire? was a good student, a clean fellow and was ambitious??,  Ide was anxious to go on with his school work but the financial offer and the inducement? held out to him were too attractive and he decided to go to Carlisle.  Little  Boy. Wilson? (Porter, Melinda Porter’s brother) his cousin) was at Haskell for one year. During that time I learned that he had been expelled from Geneva?? Nebraska for bad conduct therefore did not allow him to return to this school.  He was a very wild bad boy. 
John Asher? was a student here for some years, He was a fellow of good interactions? and everybody liked him but he got so he simply could not let liquor alone am a I sent him away till such time as he could straighten up. He took the

Keeby? cure and for a time kept straight but went to drinking again and the next thing I knew he had joined the Carlisle Football team. John is, as I have said a well meaning fellow but he is a slave to drink.
Pete Hauser? was here from 1900 until 1904. He was a bright student and a good worker. He went into athletics about 1902 and made a wonderful record but poor fellow, he was not strong enough morally to withstand the temptations that surround athletics and he got to drinking besides doing other questionable things and finally  his example became so bad that I had to expel him from school. Ever since he left school he has been carousing and

gong bad, I am told that he is doing better now but do not know except from hearsay. 
Y. Gardener?? was here for three years and was quite a young boy. 
Louis 1903 - 4 Employed at Morris, Miriam?? asst engineer
Felix was in this school for about 6 years. He is a clean fellow but not a student. Is 20 years of age at least 
You will see that Haskell is pretty well represented as to numbers but I am sorry to say not as to the average student of Haskell unclear
The Hauser's have no right in any government school as they have both been expelled from one government school

The same is true of Porter.
John Aikens was to bad an influence for Haskell.
The facts are that the Carlisle Football team is a salaried team and the men are not school boys at all.
Alfred Dubois?? who has been playing with the team for three years and not certain about him having been there this year, is a married man and has been for three years, is a blacksmith and works at his trade except during football season. He is a good fellow but is not and has not been in school for 5 years. He has drawn from $400.00 to $600.00 each season fromt eh Carlisle management for playing football.

Sen. Pratt they are not using you. as Buffalo Bill used the unclear They know they are helpless unless?? 'They use your as front' can hide behind you. You may have given money to the American Indian Magazine for print of your "What is the matter with our Indians?" It makes no difference that is a personal?? offer. but look on the back of the reprint a huge of their advertisement for the unclear

I call that using you to advertise their journal. It is [most?] [dignified? and some of us [divines?] will question the [undertaking?] of such cheapness.
Those who are using your way say that They believe as you do but they do not. They do not want to [sink as they are [hanging?] to you.

I am much gratified to have your sanction, in the main, of the subject matter of my pamphlet. Knowing your views on the subject, and, of Counsel, having my own, I was considerably concerned as to whether my efforts were such as would warrant your approval, but your kind letter has assured me on that point, much to my satisfaction.
So no "personalities" I do not know whether you mean that I should have been more sparing of your name or that I should have been less aggressive (seemingly) unclear the Commissions, or both, I presume I had better been less direct ni my style of getting at his statements, notwithstanding their absurdities; and in the future ^ will have ni mind your words of caution. In [store?] park where your name

is used it seems to me that the connection is so applicable that it does not have any appearance of motive. Still, it might be made the subject of unpleasant comments and therefore, for that reason, unnecessarily place you under embarrassment; but you know how I have always felt about the outrage that was committed where Mercer was placed where he is; and, especially, when I was avoiding any suggestion, even, of a reference to the commencement day episode I was inclined to feel warranted in striking out with somewhat of a free hand. I saw the "Outlook" article but in following so closely^ in time his interview, that I thought it better not to notice it this time. I also considered it rather weak.

The wheels will be on their way in a couple of days. They are being crated up, I believe, only Fred hasn't had time to slip in and see about them.
Will write to the girls soon. I owe them both letters. What a time you must have had when Miss Brown was there. I wish I could have peeked in for a time.
I must close now. Will write again. I have been making clocks. I have two patterns- cut direct from new styles so the girls want them? 
Write when you have a chance.
Lovingly,
Lucille.

Detroit Mich nd
223 1/2 Trumbill Ave
Dear [unclear]
I was so glad to get your letter for it's a long time between even if I do hear from home twice a week I know you are working very very hard now not having any girl. I do hope you will get one before long. I just wish I could be with you to [pitch?] in. I am so well and strong and never seem to get tired out a new experience for me. Fred is well of course and so busy. He does

sweet as can be. She is very busy sewing? these days and I pitch in whenever I go out. 
I  have just finished my Friday sweep and Mrs. Larry has gone early so as to help them out at the Smiths.
Aunt Martha is very low and barely alive and Fran? Love is just worn out for it is never a unclear now. 
They have two nurses she seemed one came back last night and I am glad unclear  unclear where yesterday. It is very hard for unclear all. 
I will go up and call on Randells? way soon and let you know how much?? it is. I should have gone before this but kept putting it off

enjoy his work although it is hustle from early morning until late at night. He was over as two days this week as Laurning? and Owasso?. I stayed with Carrie Frix a neighbor, one might and the next day went out to spend the day + night with Francis (Frank's wife) in Delray?. they live in one of his cottages but it is the dearest place and fixed up so tastily. One of J's pictures (unclear) adorns a place on the parlor and they are very proud of it. She is just as

The Feb; 8th issue of "The urrord?", the Carlisle Indian Industrial school weekly, devotes it's entire front page to a review of the recently constructed studio to be known as "The Leupp Indian Art Studio" and to be used for the purpose of developing the Artistic faculties of certain of the Carlisle pupil ni, so called, Indian Act. The whole thing is so manifest a departure from the single purpose for the which the school was founded that we cannot pass if by without some expression of disapproval.
In every instance, in human affairs, where a fatal step?

2
ni the wrong direction [crossed out]
has been taken, whether , ni the political, municipal, industrial, or educational departments of the [unclear] state, it will be found that a disaster had it's origins ni the encouragement which was given to one or more things. Tending in the wrong direction.
In no places do we see this more clearly illustrated than in schools and colleges. A school may have had a profitable and successful career for many years; and on looking into the cause we find it to be management to the constant proactise of the unclear "nip in the bud" any proposition

3
or suggestion tending toward fadisue?, which is only another name for hysterical innovation.
The most unfortunate [unclear] of these hysterical onslaughts are the public schools of large cities where the management of them changes with the shifting of party power.
The unclear of this kind of hysteria has devolved to an almost alarming extent of the Carlisle Indian Industrial school during the last three or four years. This school was established for the one single, simple? purpose of preparing the Indian youths, boys and girls, for absorption into the civilization of the country, by affording them our opportunity to learn how the world's?? work is done; and to qualify? them to become active

participants in the busy scenes of life. It was founded unclear for more than twenty years conducted strictly with one end in view to so unclear and unclear its pupils that at the end of their school work there, they could begin life in competition with those of the other races, self-supporting and self-sustaining by virtue of their ability to perform the practical, every day things that men and woman are called to do in the various pursuits of life. 
It took the pupils through eight grades of what is commonly called book study, during which time

every pupil among the boys was also learning sense one of the trades, and the girls were taught how to do the various kinds of work that fall to the lot of women to perform. One or more fairly well educated boys would leave the school also qualified either as a harnessmaker, plumber, carpenter, shoemaker, brick layer, timer, blacksmith or tailor t., Depending? as his inclination may have led him while at the school. 
Such being the purpose of the school if was for more than twenty years successfully protected against any inovations? tending to turn it away from the straight and practical line when which it was established.  Hydra-headed fadism was never permitted , during all these years, to trespass when

6
its [[[paired]]] domain. Things
apparently proper enough in their inception but really tending in a direction foreign to the real purpose of the believe were unceremoniously stopped at the operating?. Then we find that during this period none of the money? of the Government or of the pupils or of individuals was expended for the purpose of exploiting individual nations?, such as, among other things, the perpetuation of those so called curious and other articles which went to make up the paraphanellia of the Indian people in their aboriginal

They do not make new forumula?

7
life.
In fact, in those substantial days of the Carlisle school, there was a constant inflow of suggestions from numberous  directions, to the superintendent to do this and that and the other things for the uplifting of the Indian, as "an Indian", and tending?, of course, to nothing none than the keeping of him before the public as a creature as different from human beings in general that the unclear placed upon him by the word Indian must never be lost sight of.

8
In all cases, unclear, these emotional advisers failed to recieve any encouragement for the adoption of their suggestions.  In other words, in order to preserve the integrity of the school and to hold it squarely on its refined? foundation the Superintendent waged a vigorous war of disapproval of all these insidious and fanceful ministrations. As a building, in itself, we make no cry against this structure unclear erected at Carlisle for there are many uses to which it could profitably be put,but what we do object to is

9
the use purposed to be made of it.
And this for the reason, first, that there is no such thing as Indian Art in the proper reuse of the word, and, second, any attempt to perpetuate this nonexistent thing has a tendency to undermine the foundational  purpose of the school not only by its own effect but by the encouragement it gives for the introduction of other equally foreign, useless and harmful as well as wasteful innovations.
Again, open if by a strained use of the word Art if could be applied to some of the more or less skillful bandwidth of the Indian, still, it could serve no purpose to teach the Carlisle pupils to make imitations of these as they are only evidences of the dark period in Indian life of which the best that can be said is that it ought to be

10
forgotten on the march toward the more advanced life. The Indian boys and girls are not sent to Carlisle to be trained in the work of imitating their progenitons?, but instead to forget [[[all they can of]]] their past while preparing for life under modern condition. When they come out of school and have earned money in some useful occupation?. Then if they want Indian relics and curious (which in fact were never made by Indians at all) They can go into the market and buy them the same as they can imitations of the work of the Japanese and Chinamen. 
The purpose of the school is not to preserve the characteristics of Indian life but rather an determination? to the Carlisle pupils to "forget it".
the way to check an eventually disastrous adventure is to but? it real hard at the first manifestation of its tendency [[[in the wrong direction]]] Let us hope that the secretary of the interior, if he will do no more, will at least decluster?

This late unclear structure by causing to be erased them from the cards. “The Louppe Indian Art Studio” and unclear with the seal of his disapproval any further attempt of the Territory? officials of the Indian Department to memorialize the school by using their own names to identify government buildings.

The employment of educated Indians to impersonate their old time dress life and customs at St. Louis, and other expositions, and the uses of quanah?, unclear + others in the same way is hypocritical misrepresentations of facts. And thus only creates a line of prejudice feeling toward the Indian

Dear Sir:
I am in need of a few hundred dollars, and am bestirring myself to that end, anf if you will at once kindly hand me all, or part of the amount of your indebtedness, you will confer a favor.
Very truly yours,

Dear Mr Montezuma, 
I am sorry I could not have attended to this matter personally, in which event I would have sent you no bill at all, but in as much as I could not do so and had to send a reporter in my place, I have charged you just what he charged me. 
Gratefully yours,
F. B. Dickinson
